TextView.android:text: Peonies are perennial flowering plants of the genus Paeonia, the only genus in the family Paeoniaceae, comprising around 30â€“40 species. They are best known for their large, lush, and often fragrant blooms that come in a wide range of colors, including white, pink, red, and occasionally yellow or purple. Native primarily to Asia, with some species in Europe and western North America, peonies thrive in temperate climates and are widely cultivated as ornamental garden plants. The leaves are compound and deeply lobed, typically arranged alternately on the stem, with a smooth or slightly serrated margin. Peony flowers can be single, semi-double, or fully double, with a dense layering of petals in cultivated varieties. They bloom in late spring to early summer, with each flower typically lasting about 7 to 10 days. Peonies grow from thick, fleshy root systems and can live for decades when properly cared for. Symbolizing prosperity, honor, and romance, peonies hold cultural significance in Chinese and Japanese traditions and are prized in floral design and wedding arrangements.
